story:
BECOMING IRANIAN BOOK

Becoming Iranian is a book of 81 photographs, captions and notes that give vision to a misunderstood place. The book is my way of answering a question: what does it mean for me to be Iranian as a young man born and raised in the United States?

THE STORY

On September 10th, 2011 the only thing I could think about was how to come up with $10,000 to pay the Iranian conscription board and avoid 21 months of military service. It was 91 days since I landed in Tehran which meant I wouldn’t be allowed to leave without serving or paying. I could have left earlier, but I needed more time.

In June 2011, I moved to Iran to spend a year understanding the place where my father was born and raised, and to which I had never been. I went in blind, not speaking Farsi, to meet my family, to ask what it meant for me to be Iranian. My tools were a camera, dozens of journals and a tape recorder. 

Over the next two and a half years I photographed my way through Iran. It took a year to pay off the military, teaching English for $3.40 an hour. I made friends, fell in and out of love and joined the ranks of Tehran’s wandering souls. I traveled throughout the country, road tripping with friends through Iranian Kurdistan, Azerbaijan and the Turkmen Sahra. I hitchhiked across the central Iranian desert from Isfahan to the Afghan border near Tabas and ferried between the islands of the Persian Gulf. 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We are asking for your help in raising $11,350 to fund the final editing, design, and printing of the book. Every perk is 100%  original and unique; from original content and design to unique perspectives on Iran.


Editing $2,000: I've teamed up with New York City artist and master black and white printer Barron Rachman, www.barronrachman.com. Barron’s commitment to image construction is uncompromising. In addition to dedication to form and design Barron has unique experience in the region working as a photojournalist in the middle east throughout the 1990’s and early 2000’s.

Design $2,000: Barron and I will also oversee the design team.

Printing $6,140: At 500 units, the cost per book allows us to offer the final copy at an accessible price. Our goal is to give as many people access to the work as possible without losing the cohesion of the work.

ISBN Number and Barcode $160: In order for the book to be distributed beyond the campaign we'll need it to be identified with an International Standard Book Number and an individual Universal Product Code.

Indiegogo $1050: Estimating the cost associated with Indiegogo is difficult because it depends on the number of donations and the method of donating. Indiegogo's base fee is 5% of the total funds raised. They also charge 3% plus $0.30 per credit card transaction or 3-5% for each Pay-Pal transaction. Estimating 500 donations, mostly via credit card a rough cut for Indiegogo is $1,050.


If our goal is not reached all the funds will go toward the production of a smaller version of the same book. Our aim is to produce a final piece, not simply a series of photographs, but a story. A document.



THE IMPACT

The world is dominated by storybook images, sound bites and immediate conclusions, so much so that complexity and nuance are often lost. Conclusions aren’t drawn from a review of news outlets, they are doled out by them. Becoming Iranian was photographed over two and a half years. It took a full calendar year to edit through 26,110 images alongside dozens of journals and other documents. By the time the final copy comes off the press another year will have passed. That's how long it takes to produce a project of this magnitude. 

Iran is changing. 70% of the population of Iran is under age 35, 60% of all university students are women. Technology is reaching places at a speed not seen in the history of the county. Becoming Iranian captures a moment in Iran that won't be repeated for another thousand years through the lens of personal identity.

I don't shy away from the complexities of Iran, identity and dual societies. I embrace them. Becoming Iranian is not a series of conclusions; I leave that to the reader, trusting that individuals can and should reach their own understanding. 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

It is a risk pricing using 500 units as a reference point. The margin of error is as low as it can be. When asked what qualifies me to overcome this challenge the answer is simple. I’ve raised $10,000 once before, only it wasn’t for 500 books. It was to get home. 


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Every penny counts and we’ve developed a series of perks that are 100% unique and original. For as low as $5.00 I’ll send you an original signed postcard from one of my favorite images of the series. But the success of the Becoming Iranian campaign isn’t just in raising funds: it's spreading the word. If you know someone who would be interested, who shares a similar story or who would benefit this project please share it! Post it on your wall, your twitter feed, blogs and anywhere else you think it would help!

story:
Hi everyone! 
I'm Nicoletta Rosellini (singer of Kalidia and Walk in Darkness) and if you are reading this probably you know me a little bit.

I'm launching this funding campaign to help one of my best friends and a truly talented photographer: Luna La Chimia. If you are connected with me, you surely saw some of her shots!

Unfortunately, last weekend we were shooting a music video and, on the way back home, Luna's backpack got stolen on the train. That backpack contained lots of her professional equipement.
I can't help her to get back the awesome shots she did in the last days but I can help by showing you her art and getting in touch with lots of incredible musicians to offer you something unique among the perks! Backing this fund raising will help Luna to portray music through her eyes once again.
 

What We Need (or... What We Lost!) 

The stolen backpack contained:

  • Nikon D810 Body - paid ∼ 3500€ (current value: ∼ 2000€)
  • Lens NIKKOR 24-70mm f/2.8G ED AF-S: ∼ 2000€
  • 2 extra Nikon batteries EN-EL15 Li-ion and lots of Lexar (CF and SD) memory cards = ∼ 500€

...plus all the photos, shows pass and other memorabilia collected during her work, but no money can bring them back.

I'm setting the goal at 3500€ - this amount is enough to get her back behind the lenses with a new body camera. But I'm pretty sure you will surprise me! Any extra euros gained will help to get back the other lost equipment.

What You Get

I must say music is like a big family: I wrote to some of my colleagues and they were more than happy to help - the perks included some autographed prints of photos taken by Luna!
I also added some of my personal memorabilia and, of course, some of my voice!
Of course, at some point I had to warn Luna I was launching this campaign (because I needed the photos!) and she wanted to offer her own skills and talent (as soon as she got the new equipment): you can book her for your band (both studio and concerts) or...for personal shooting!

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us hugely sharing this campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter or any other social media!!  THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

PS: If you do not have a credit card, but still wish to contribute to this campaign, please contact me directly at nicolettarosellini@gmail.com!

PS2: If you are an artist and want to donate some goodies for this campaign, please contact me directly at nicolettarosellini@gmail.com!

story:
Summary

In 2016 we started our first Indiegogo campaign for "Those Who Remain" and we were blown away by the support we got for the project. Since then we have been working hard in Moldova with our deportees to tell their story and bare witness to the injustices they faced under the Soviet Union. The description of our project is;

In Moldova, there is a lost generation of children who were deported with their families, without trial, to the Eastern Soviet States in the early 1900's. These children are now living the twilight years of their lives with the memories of their deportation deeply ingrained in their minds. Those Who Remain explores the personal histories of surviving deportees as a way to provide a platform for sharing and exploring the issues and history of the deportations on a national and international level.  

We want to share these story without bias, in a truthful, genuine manner and in a way that gives deportees back the voices that were stripped from them.

And we have done just that! We have worked to gather stories and put them together to tell the beautiful and in-depth stories around the deportations. While our initial Indiegogo campaign allowed us to start the project, our Indiegogo campaign now will allow us to finish the story with the completion of Stage 2 shooting and completing all photography work in Moldova. Before we continue we want to share some story excerpts from the work we have done thus far;

One December afternoon Ana and I went to her mother's gravesite to visit at my request. On the way there, Ana joked that she was calling her mother to tell her she was coming. "Mama? Mama? Can you hear me?" She said into her hand, "We are coming to visit OK? I am coming with [Clary]." I smiled as we walked arm in arm.

When we arrived and Ana stepped closer to her mother's grave she began to cry, "Mother I am here." She kept saying, "I am here, mother. I have come." As we leave she laid to small sweet cookies on the gravestone. "These are for my mother," she says, "but the birds will eat them for her."

When Pasha's son, Leonid, came to visit from Ukraine, she lamented that he spent so little time with her. Leonid, in his youth, was a professional soccer player, a fact that Pasha is proud of despite the fact that it required him to be away often. One day during Leonid’s visit, wearing a red dress sent to her from family in Italy, she said, "I dressed nicely, yet Leonid doesn't come." Leonid instead decided to spend much of his trip visiting his cousin, Alex, Ana's son.

Both Pasha’s sister, Ana, and her daughter-in-law, Ludmilla lament that same fact. “As you can see she has no one,” they tell me one evening, “She has no one to come visit her and she is very lonely.” Ana is even moved to tears that the family cannot do more for her.

Moldova is the poorest country in Europe and as a result life can be extremely hard. Ludmilla has to travel to Italy every three months to work to pay off the wedding of her eldest child, Ana’s grandchild, Ioana, and the family worries about Pasha’s death. “That would be a tragedy if she died,” she says, “We cannot pay for the funeral and my son, Pavel, will be getting married as well.” Ana cries to me, “Please do something for Pasha, please!” “I will try.” I say, but I little know what to do.

A common theme to the deportee’s story is that the story did not end after Stalin’s death. The larger story is about the social and political repression felt by deportees after they returned to Moldova, as well as the long process of building their lives back up after having everything taken away. The resilience of the deportees who experienced this history shows that through great pain, life does go on.

Ion says goodbye to Nina one last time at her gravesite on November 27th, 2016. I had called Thanksgiving day in hopes that I could spend "Old Christmas," the orthodox epiphany date of Christmas in Moldova held on January 7th.

Ion answered the phone. When I asked how he was doing he simply replied, "Bad." "Why bad?" I asked. "Nina a morit." He said. Nina died.

I was shook by the unexpected loss. For the next couple of days I was sure that I had misheard Ion. 'My Romanian is bad, I couldn't have understood correctly,' I thought. But unfortunately, when I went to their home, there Nina was. This beautiful light of a woman was gone.

 

What Have We Done So Far?

In short, A LOT! Our team has done a number of things for the project including;

  • Working one-on-one with deportees to cover all aspects in life from daily life to celebrations, from holidays to funerals, from the exciting to the dull, and everything in between
  • Developing and hosting oral history workshops across Moldova so that we can bring together people interested in the deportees history, as well as train the next generation of photographers, videographers and historians around this subject
  • Worked one-on-one with our animation partner to begin developing documentary animation for the project
  • Translated pages and pages of interviews to be shared with English-speaking audiences
  • Interviewed dozens of deportees across Moldova so that they can be archived and shared with future generations and researchers

But there is still more to do! 

What We Need to Finish

Our needs are quite simple, we need to finish shooting on location in Moldova. This includes traveling to the home-villages of former deportees and finding the homes they were evicted from, the train stations they we deported from and the traces of history that has been left in the Moldovan earth. Below we have a map of shooting locations;

  • Floresti 
    • The train station Pasha and Ana were deported from to Kazakhstan
  • Nemteni
    • The village Nina and her family moved back to when they returned to Moldova, her sister is currently living there and we plan to interview her as well
  • Mereni
    • The village Ion's family lived in before their deportation and returned to after their release
  • Northern Moldova, Glodeni region
    • We will be going to a region of northwestern Moldova to try and find Nina's mother and father's original home before they were deported
  • Chisinau
    • The old train station in Chisinau where hundreds of thousands of Moldovans were deported
    • The largest cemetery of Eastern Europe, where many former deportees are buried
    • The Museum of History and Ethnography, where our animation partner, Ghenadie, lives and works and who we will be working with to make a series of animated documentary videos based on deportee stories.

In addition to all of these locations, we will be working with local historians to find and document regional areas associated with the deportations in order to expand the story and how it etched Moldova's history as a whole. We will also continue to conduct a series of deportee interviews with deportees across Moldova to share them with you once the project is complete! Once we have completed travel to each of these locations in Moldova we will start and finish compiling all of the work into one large exhibition which can be shared with our audience.

 

What are We Working Against?

As we explained in our previous campaign;

We are working with a number of Moldovan partner organizations to get this project off the ground, and to keep it accurate to the experiences of Moldovans during the Soviet era. This is a complex and deep story and we recognize the importance of having Moldovan partners on board to tell it correctly.

Our biggest risk right now is time. Many of our deportees are very elderly and will not be with us much longer. We want to make sure their voices are preserved before they leave us. By helping us start this project now, not later, we can insure that their voices are preserved. We have relationships with these people and they want to tell their story. 

Unfortunately, time has caught up with us and we lost one of our amazing deportees, Nina Postica. Nina died on Thanksgiving of 2016 and it was a surprising and terrible blow for the entire team. As part of the project we documented her funeral and continue to work with her husband, Ion, to tell their story. This issue continues to be something we work against. We have only a limited time to work with our deportees and we have to be sure that their story gets told.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't make a contribution? There are other ways you can help! The easiest is to spread the word far and wide. When we first moved to Moldova we had no idea about this story and we believe that is not a good thing. So share the story and our fundraising by sharing this campaign or by following and sharing our work on the social media sites below:

Facebook

Twitter

Tumblr 

Patreon - The best way to support us long term is to become a patreon for the work! You can give a little less for longer and help us from month to month!!!

Want to help us fundraise in other ways? You can also host an event! Talk to your local institutions and see if they are interested in helping us host a fundraising event for the project. Events not only help us spread the word, they expand our audience and offer a fun time in the process! To contact us email: macles.estes7@gmail.com
story_txt:
Summary
In 2016 we started our first Indiegogo campaign for "Those Who Remain" and we were blown away by the support we got for the project. Since then we have been working hard in Moldova with our deportees to tell their story and bare witness to the injustices they faced under the Soviet Union. The description of our project is;
In Moldova, there is a lost generation of children who were deported with their families, without trial, to the Eastern Soviet States in the early 1900's. These children are now living the twilight years of their lives with the memories of their deportation deeply ingrained in their minds. Those Who Remain explores the personal histories of surviving deportees as a way to provide a platform for sharing and exploring the issues and history of the deportations on a national and international level.  
We want to share these story without bias, in a truthful, genuine manner and in a way that gives deportees back the voices that were stripped from them.
And we have done just that! We have worked to gather stories and put them together to tell the beautiful and in-depth stories around the deportations. While our initial Indiegogo campaign allowed us to start the project, our Indiegogo campaign now will allow us to finish the story with the completion of Stage 2 shooting and completing all photography work in Moldova. Before we continue we want to share some story excerpts from the work we have done thus far;

One December afternoon Ana and I went to her mother's gravesite to visit at my request. On the way there, Ana joked that she was calling her mother to tell her she was coming. "Mama? Mama? Can you hear me?" She said into her hand, "We are coming to visit OK? I am coming with [Clary]." I smiled as we walked arm in arm.
When we arrived and Ana stepped closer to her mother's grave she began to cry, "Mother I am here." She kept saying, "I am here, mother. I have come." As we leave she laid to small sweet cookies on the gravestone. "These are for my mother," she says, "but the birds will eat them for her."

When Pasha's son, Leonid, came to visit from Ukraine, she lamented that he spent so little time with her. Leonid, in his youth, was a professional soccer player, a fact that Pasha is proud of despite the fact that it required him to be away often. One day during Leonid’s visit, wearing a red dress sent to her from family in Italy, she said, "I dressed nicely, yet Leonid doesn't come." Leonid instead decided to spend much of his trip visiting his cousin, Alex, Ana's son.
Both Pasha’s sister, Ana, and her daughter-in-law, Ludmilla lament that same fact. “As you can see she has no one,” they tell me one evening, “She has no one to come visit her and she is very lonely.” Ana is even moved to tears that the family cannot do more for her.
Moldova is the poorest country in Europe and as a result life can be extremely hard. Ludmilla has to travel to Italy every three months to work to pay off the wedding of her eldest child, Ana’s grandchild, Ioana, and the family worries about Pasha’s death. “That would be a tragedy if she died,” she says, “We cannot pay for the funeral and my son, Pavel, will be getting married as well.” Ana cries to me, “Please do something for Pasha, please!” “I will try.” I say, but I little know what to do.
A common theme to the deportee’s story is that the story did not end after Stalin’s death. The larger story is about the social and political repression felt by deportees after they returned to Moldova, as well as the long process of building their lives back up after having everything taken away. The resilience of the deportees who experienced this history shows that through great pain, life does go on.

Ion says goodbye to Nina one last time at her gravesite on November 27th, 2016. I had called Thanksgiving day in hopes that I could spend "Old Christmas," the orthodox epiphany date of Christmas in Moldova held on January 7th.
Ion answered the phone. When I asked how he was doing he simply replied, "Bad." "Why bad?" I asked. "Nina a morit." He said. Nina died.
I was shook by the unexpected loss. For the next couple of days I was sure that I had misheard Ion. 'My Romanian is bad, I couldn't have understood correctly,' I thought. But unfortunately, when I went to their home, there Nina was. This beautiful light of a woman was gone.
 
What Have We Done So Far?
In short, A LOT! Our team has done a number of things for the project including;

Working one-on-one with deportees to cover all aspects in life from daily life to celebrations, from holidays to funerals, from the exciting to the dull, and everything in between
Developing and hosting oral history workshops across Moldova so that we can bring together people interested in the deportees history, as well as train the next generation of photographers, videographers and historians around this subject
Worked one-on-one with our animation partner to begin developing documentary animation for the project
Translated pages and pages of interviews to be shared with English-speaking audiences
Interviewed dozens of deportees across Moldova so that they can be archived and shared with future generations and researchers

But there is still more to do! 

What We Need to Finish
Our needs are quite simple, we need to finish shooting on location in Moldova. This includes traveling to the home-villages of former deportees and finding the homes they were evicted from, the train stations they we deported from and the traces of history that has been left in the Moldovan earth. Below we have a map of shooting locations;



Floresti The train station Pasha and Ana were deported from to Kazakhstan


NemteniThe village Nina and her family moved back to when they returned to Moldova, her sister is currently living there and we plan to interview her as well


MereniThe village Ion's family lived in before their deportation and returned to after their release


Northern Moldova, Glodeni regionWe will be going to a region of northwestern Moldova to try and find Nina's mother and father's original home before they were deported


Chisinau
The old train station in Chisinau where hundreds of thousands of Moldovans were deported
The largest cemetery of Eastern Europe, where many former deportees are buried
The Museum of History and Ethnography, where our animation partner, Ghenadie, lives and works and who we will be working with to make a series of animated documentary videos based on deportee stories.



In addition to all of these locations, we will be working with local historians to find and document regional areas associated with the deportations in order to expand the story and how it etched Moldova's history as a whole. We will also continue to conduct a series of deportee interviews with deportees across Moldova to share them with you once the project is complete! Once we have completed travel to each of these locations in Moldova we will start and finish compiling all of the work into one large exhibition which can be shared with our audience.

 
What are We Working Against?
As we explained in our previous campaign;
We are working with a number of Moldovan partner organizations to get this project off the ground, and to keep it accurate to the experiences of Moldovans during the Soviet era. This is a complex and deep story and we recognize the importance of having Moldovan partners on board to tell it correctly.
Our biggest risk right now is time. Many of our deportees are very elderly and will not be with us much longer. We want to make sure their voices are preserved before they leave us. By helping us start this project now, not later, we can insure that their voices are preserved. We have relationships with these people and they want to tell their story. 
Unfortunately, time has caught up with us and we lost one of our amazing deportees, Nina Postica. Nina died on Thanksgiving of 2016 and it was a surprising and terrible blow for the entire team. As part of the project we documented her funeral and continue to work with her husband, Ion, to tell their story. This issue continues to be something we work against. We have only a limited time to work with our deportees and we have to be sure that their story gets told.

 
Other Ways You Can Help
Can't make a contribution? There are other ways you can help! The easiest is to spread the word far and wide. When we first moved to Moldova we had no idea about this story and we believe that is not a good thing. So share the story and our fundraising by sharing this campaign or by following and sharing our work on the social media sites below:
Facebook

Events not only help us spread the word, they expand our audience and offer a fun time in the process! To contact us email: macles.estes7@gmail.com

story:
Hello, my name is Mary, a SoCal professional photographer. I am also an active mermaid and adore creating magical merfotography! 

I am building a 2020 calendar filled with mermaids and magic! But let's also raise some awareness towards a cause everyone should lend a hand in, Ocean Conservation. A big part of the mermaid community is bringing awareness to how we treat our aquatic ecosystem and how we can do better to protect it.

For each photoshoot and calendar sold a portion of the proceeds will go to help Ocean Conservation; I have chosen the organization Oceana.org to donate a percentage of each donation and calendar sale. Oceana is dedicated to protecting and restoring the world's oceans on a global scale. 

The calendar will feature 12 months of amazing Mermaid Photoshoots and you can be one of them! As one of the rewards for this campaign you can snag a month in the calendar! 

For more details please check out the rewards you can purchase to support! 

I am deeply grateful for your support of my art and helping to help our oceans! 

If you'd like to check out more of my work you can find me on social media @MoJophoto59 or Mojophoto59.com

story:
Barbara Wasiak: Retrospective.

Sensoria Festival 2018

This retrospective exhibition will include work spanning the 80's to the early years of the new Millennium and promises to be lively and poignant journey through Bab's eyes. The show will include "Lady's Bridge", a photographic essay developed over several years and the project that was closest to her heart. The exhibition offers a wonderful opportunity to celebrate the life and work of Barbara Wasiak and bring her work to a new audience.

Barbara was well known for her photographs of Sheffield music people which she created during the 80's, 90's and beyond.  Her archive includes of Cabaret Voltaire, CHAKK, Hula, Tree Bound Story, and many more.  She also documented Sheffield's vibrant underground club scene.

Babs was also an accomplished social documentary photographer, capturing the grit and humour of everyday life over a period of some 2 decades. The retrospective will feature this largely unseen aspect of Barbara's work and will provide a unique insight into the context in which such a diverse and vibrant musical culture emerged and flourished.


This major retrospective is an initiative developed in partnership between Sensoria  & Jose Snook
The exhibition will be curated and produced by Jose, to whom Barbara bequeathed her archive. Barbara & Jose worked together on many projects including "Healthier Living" and "Catwalk Catastrophe" which were commissioned by Sheffield's Untitled Gallery.  Work from these humorous and satirical projects will also be included in the retrospective.

Two books will also be produced to accompany and complement the exhibition:
a catalogue of her social documentary work, which will also include selected images from "Lady's Bridge" and a monograph of photographs relative to Sheffield's music scene.

The costs & how you can help.
Producing an exhibition that does justice to Barbara Wasiak's legacy will cost £7500.
We hope that people will share our enthusiam for this project and offer their support.
You can help us make this happen by:
Donating using the BACK IT button.
And/or buy one or two of the perks, which include  a selection of limited edition prints.

 

The Team
Jose Snook
Jose has over 25 years of project development & management in the arts & heritage sector. She has curated and produced  arts & heritage  events & photographic exhibitions in Derby, South Yorkshire and Northumberland. Having worked very closely with Barbara in the past, Jose understands  Barbara's vision and importantly has the necessary skills and patience to realise this exhibition to Barbara's exacting standards.

Sensoria
Sensoria is the UK's festival of music and film presenting a heady mix of live music, outdoor screenings, exhibitions and installations.  Sensoria has welcomed guests including Laurie Anderson, Jarvis Cocker, Bill Drummond, Nitin Sawhney, Christopher Eccleston, Edwyn Collins, Paddy Considine, British Sea Power, Julien Temple,  Chris and Cosey, Tim Burgess, Mary Ann Hobbs, Alan McGee and many more. SensoriaPro is our informal Industry Day that brings together a wide range of creatives to discuss the latest developments in music and the moving image.

Now entering its 10th year, Sensoria places a spotlight on many of the city's hidden gems. We've thrown the doors open to Sheffield's working law courts, the now demolished Grosvenor hotel ballroom,  B&C Co-operative department store, plus Abbeydale Picture House after several years of closure,  providing an atmospheric backdrop to some landmark gigs and events . The festival is also synonymous with outdoor screenings and city centre Drive-Ins.

story:
Was wir alleine nicht schaffen....

Fotoreportage & Ausstellung

Seit 4 Jahren pilgert die Ergotherapeutin Christin den Jakobsweg.

Sie unternimmt diese Reise aber nicht allein sondern ermöglicht Menschen mit Handicap das pilgern.

Christin übernimmt hier nicht nur den Part der Reisebegleitung, Therapeutin und Pflegerin sondern schiebt ihre Patienten hunderte von Kilometern über den Jakobsweg in Spanien.

Immer wieder kommt die Frage auf: Muss man immer alles alleine schaffen in der heutigen Gesellschaft ? 

Was sind eigentlich Barrieren ? - ausser den Grenzen im Kopf.

Dieses Jahr führt der Weg über den portugiesischen Jakobsweg,

230 Kilometer von Porto nach Santiago.

Die Hamburger Fotografin Annemone Taake wird den Weg fotografisch begleiten und einen täglichen Blog führen.

Aus diesen Bildern soll eine Reportage & Ausstellung entstehen, die Mut macht eigene Grenzen zu sprengen und Aufmerksamkeit auf das wunderbare Wirken einzelner Menschen lenkt.

Im kleinen die Welten anderer verändern ist möglich !

 

Was wir brauchen & Was man bekommt

Wir greifen nach den Sternen!

Das Projekt wird bereits mit sehr viel Mühe selbst finanziert und auch die Fotografin 

bringt Reisekosten, Zeit und Engagement mit.

Ihre Unterstützung sichert uns:

Ein kleines Honorar bzw. Reisekosten- Unterstützung für unsere Fotografin !

Die Drucke der Bilder auf leichte Kunststoffplatten & Aufhängungen ( 14 - 18 )

Drucke von Flyern & Ausstellungsankündigung vorerst in Hamburg und Erfurt

Drucke der Reiseberichte der Fotografin ( Schrift & Bild in Journalform )


Warum das Alles ?

Weil wir die Reise lieben, weil Steine dazu da sind aus dem Weg geräumt zu werden und wir verstanden haben, dass man als Einzelner sehr wohl die Möglichkeit hat Welten zu verändern & die Möglichkeit geben eine Reise zu machen, die sonst nie möglich wäre.

Wir wollen eine Ausstellung machen die berührt und andere Wege aufzeigt.

Und vor allem dieses wunderbare Projekt, die Kraft & den Mut zeigen wollen der dahinter steckt!


Man muß seine Segel in den
unendlichen Wind stellen.
Dann erst werden wir spüren,
welcher Fahrt wir fähig sind.

( Alfred Delp )


for all our english speaking followers:

A pilgrimage on the St. James way with disabilities. 

Since 4 years occupational therapist Christin Scholze takes her patients including their wheelchairs on a pilgrimage. 

Now we want to produce a photo report including a photo exhibition with photos taken by our photographer annemone taake who will follow us on our journey.

Please don´t hesitate to support us & share some love !

Select a perk

- The scalloped shell - €10

You will receive a huge Thank you and we will publish your name on the golden "board of honorees".

-The hiking cane - €25

We will take your wishes and prayers along our pilgrimage and bring a present "wish from the heart" to the "end of the world" and we will publish your name on the golden "board of honorees".

- The pilgrim - €50

You will receive a post card from our trip on the St. James way and we will publish your name on the golden "board of honorees".

- The Pope..In person.  -€100

You will receive a post card from our trip on the St. James way, we will take your wishes and prayers along our pilgrimage and bring a present "wish from the heart" to the "end of the world", we will publish your name on the golden "board of honorees", and you will receive a limited photo print (20x30cm)

-St. James -€200

 You will receive a post card from our trip on the St. James way, we will take your wishes and prayers along our pilgrimage and bring a present "wish from the heart" to the "end of the world", we will publish your name on the golden "board of honorees", and you will receive a limited photo print (30x40cm)

story:
In the fall of 2011, I started a project taking photographs and conducting interviews with yogis. I deliberately chose a style of photography that is some distance from the aesthetic of commercial yoga photography - I wanted to capture the asana (or postures) in a very different way than what we usually see in magazines or on the internet. The interviews were also illuminating - they revealed the commonalities we experience about the benefits of yoga, and the struggles that we all have maintaining a regular practice while still meeting the commitments of our lives.  

Where the project's at: 

The photographs and interviews are all done, and it's ready to go to press. I'm raising funds to cover the cost of turning the project into a book. 

If you want to preview the project, you can check it out at http://108photographs.wordpress.com. 

What you'll get: 

I have a variety of perks, ranging from a postcard to a hard copy of the book, and even up to a photo shoot! Ideally, I'd like everyone to receive something tangible, so I added a new perk for donations under 25$. 

What I need:

Your support! But it doesn't have to be in the form of money - sharing the project is important too because one of the goals of the project is to present an alternate image of yoga and yogis - and to do that, people need to see it! So if you can't spare some money, spare some time and send it out to your contacts! 

When will I get my book?

I'm collecting all the donations and will place one large order at the beginning of April, so hopfully your book will arrive before the end of the month. If you've ordered an e-book, then that should arrive much sooner - possibly even before the end of the campaign!

story:
“A Year In The Life Of An Amateur Photographer”.

I started over a year ago where I set out to take a picture a day for one year. After each photo was taken I would upload it to Facebook and allow my friends to suggest names for each image.

The intent of this project was to capture riveting images, and have them put into a book(s). While out on my year long journey,  I noticed that there were a great deal of homeless veterans on the streets of Dallas, as well as, veterans that are disabled and wounded warriors.

After a great deal of prayer and guidance from the Lord,  I realized I wanted to do something to stop the epidemic that is not only effecting Dallas, but this nation. And I had the tools at my hands to do so. The statistics of homeless veterans are  staggering. About 1 in 5 homeless people on the streets of Dallas are vets, that comes to a little over 2500 and climbing each day  with the returning vets from Iraq and Afghanistan.

This project is to raise fund and awareness to benefit wounded and homeless veterans here in Dallas. I am not benefiting from it one bit. I hope you will feel the same as me, and the urgency to do whatever we can to make a difference in this growing crisis. I would like to thank you all in advance for your support and assistance in making this project come to life.

Semper Fi and Blessings,

Brian Cornett

story:
Why a book on Vancouver?

It all started some 10 years ago with a handful of photographs of iconic Vancouver landmarks including the Orpheum, the Marine Building and Siwash Rock to name a few. Produced as a small collection of commercial art prints, these led to the creation of my Vancouver Series of Fine Art Canvases, which has now grown to over 100 images.

Throughout this journey, what has always been magical for me are the connections people have with my work and their fond memories of places and time spent with their loved ones.

As the rapid urban development of Vancouver continues and the city's post-war character diminishes, I feel it is important to capture and preserve these experiences in a beautiful fine art book that can be cherished now and by future generations.


How you can support this project

I've decided to self-publish the book mostly so I can maintain creative control. This means I have to pay for printing and other costs in advance.

So I'm asking for your support to help fund this through pre-sales, early bird specials and value-added packages (see perks in the right-hand side column on this page).

The retail cost of the book will be $55 Cdn (unsigned).

Where your contributions will go

With the design, editing and content research taken care of, what the costs really amount to are for the printing, marketing and some other costs as follows:

  • Marketing Budget ~ $2,000
  • ISBN, copyright, & barcode ~ $350
  • Printing, Packing & Shipping ~ $16,000
  • Crowdfunding fees + Wire fees ~ $1,500.
  • TOTAL: $19,850

Team & Timeframe

I have put together a great team and have the support of my fabulous retail partners including the amazing people at Parliament Interiors in Gastown. We have prepared as much as possible to make sure our project goes smoothly. From artwork, writing, design and production, everything is on schedule to meet our printing deadline scheduled for late July. We will using Friesens Printing—a respected Canadian company and book specialists who have been immensely supportive already. We will receive copies of the book in September and will keep you posted on the book launch date and place!

Wholesale Opportunities

We are offering the book for wholesale in bulk quantities. If you're interested then please get in touch.

Other Ways You Can Help

Contributing is not all about money.

You can really help me by getting the word out about my book campaign as we have only limited resources to do this. You can like our Facebook page and please refer me to anyone you think may be interested in my book or seeing my work.

My Story

As a contemporary fine art photographer, my art is inspired by the beauty of the natural world and the mysteries of life. I am a full time artist who lives and works out of my studio in North Vancouver.  I have a master’s degree in Photography from the Royal College of Art (RCA) London, UK.

This body of work began as an exploration into the city of my birth. I have a romantic view of Vancouver which is colored by my parent's stories from their youth. They met during World War II and began their relationship in Vancouver. During the war, my mom worked in a factory building Catalina Airplanes and afterwards in various jobs including as a housekeeper at the Hotel Vancouver.  My Father and his parents lived on Cornwall in the heart of Kitsilano. He went to University at UBC while my Mother worked to support them both. They frequented Granville Street, the Sylvia Hotel and walked often in Stanley Park.

I have continued their tradition of loving and living in Vancouver, returning after some years in England. During my University days I worked summer jobs at various city buildings including the majestic Marine Building on Burrard Street. It was an honour to have spent some time in that grand building. 

The imagery is created to reflect Vancouver’s soul which includes it’s history and ‘lived-in’ feeling.  I want the images to have character and body—to show the city in all it’s glory. By adding layers of distress, what is the subject and the history of that representation becomes entwined.

Perk Options ~ Fine Art Prints

Orpheum, Yale Hotel, Misty Seawall, Sylvia Hotel, Lions Gate Bridge.

Perk Options ~ Large Canvases

Orpheum

The Lions

Sylvia Hotel

story:
The Photo Mural Project

The Andean Alliance for Sustainable Development (AASD) is an NGO based in the Sacred Valley of Peru.

The AASD uses innovative solutions to alleviate the effects of poverty, marginalization, and social injustices that hinder community development and well-being.  The AASD harnesses collective intelligence to support community-led development in the highlands of Peru.

In addition to combating the more serious issues in the Sacred Valley, the AASD also has initiates project of community empowerment. 

The Children of Inti

The Children of Inti project began by teaching art classes in the indigenous village of Pampacorral, in the Sacred Valley of Peru.

Resting 13,000 feet above sea level, the village has of around 100 students. 

Over the past years, the AASD has raised funds to purchase digital cameras for the students – most of whom have never been exposed to technology before.  AASD’s Eric Ebner taught photography to more than 30 students between the ages of 10 and 18. 

The course produced incredible photography.  We were so amazed at the scenic photos the students took of their family, their community, their every day lives that we were motivated to provide them with a unique opportunity to share these images their beyond their classroom.

So on March 21st, 2015 – we want to take 30 students to the city of Cusco to post a large photo mural right in the Historic Center in the main Plaza de Armas.

We want to provide this opportunity for the students because webelieve in their creativity and the empowerment it triggers.  The photo mural project enables the students to have a fun experience and to tell their story. 

One incredible day, 30 students, 30 photos – and surely a day of at least 30 big smiles!

Thank you for your support.


What We Need & What You Get

To realize this dream, we need your support.  Your donations to this project will cover the transportation costs to and from Cusco (which is a 3 hour drive one way), through your contribution the students will be provided a meal and funds raised will also go towards the printing of their poster-sized photographs for the mural along with printing additional postcard size images to share and distribute at the big event! 

Your donations will help make this field trip possible!  We believe that the mural will brighten up the city and the lives of those who will see them.  Most importantly, this day will be so exceptional and fun for the students!  Any donation is gratefully appreciated!

In return for your support, we will be sending digital print or printed photographs from the students !  


The Impact

Our goal is to provide the students with an epic experience to share their talent and their story.  We believe that the impact is truly immeasurable - it is empowering and encouraging.  If the main impact that results from this day is that the students have a fun time, then we will have achieved our aim.  We do believe that their photos will result in a beautiful mural that can be enjoyed by all!


Challenges

Rain or shine, we are going to get the photo mural project up!  We hope that we can meet our funding aim to cover the costs.  


Other Ways You Can Help

In case you are as excited about this project as we are but are unable to contribute, you can help by sharing our campaign on your social media platforms, like us on facebook and help us spread the word.


Thank You!

story:
The OUTREACH program is the start of discovering your potential, and is committed to seeing you succeed. —Ebti Nabag, artist, teacher, and 2011 participant


Every year, with the support of individuals like you, Gallery 44 offers free, creative workshops to youth from under served communities across the Greater Toronto Area.

OUTREACH, an award-winning education program designed for youth, uses photography as a medium and catalyst for creative self-expression. Engaging youth in a process they direct from beginning to end, OUTREACH helps to break down barriers to the arts, and encourages independence and creative growth.

"I love this program. It keeps me active, it keeps me out of trouble, it keeps my mind going...it makes me see things in a whole different way.” —Rickson Thom, OUTREACH participant, 2014

Photo by Jocelyn Reynolds, OUTREACH instructor 2015


In conjunction with the program’s artistic goals, OUTREACH aspires to provide a better sense of connection with the self and with peers, while creating a platform to address issues significant to the participants. OUTREACH helps build confidence through artistic production and participation. 

Photo by Heran Genene, OUTREACH participant 2014


About Gallery 44

Gallery 44 Centre for Contemporary Photography is a non-profit artist-run centre committed to photography as a multi-faceted and ever-changing art form. Founded in 1979 to establish a supportive environment for the development of photography, Gallery 44’s mandate is to provide a context for reflection and dialogue on contemporary photography and its related practices.

Gallery 44 offers exhibition and publication opportunities to national and international artists, award-winning education programs, and affordable production facilities for artists. Through its programs Gallery 44 is engaged in changing conceptions of the photographic image and its modes of production.

“The OUTREACH program was my first official introduction to the magic of darkroom film photography. G44 gave me a chance to believe in myself and what I was capable of achieving. The OUTREACH program changes the lives of youth; I am a living example. For once in my life I was given an opportunity to believe in myself and to explore a new medium.”
—Giselle Mira Diaz, OUTREACH participant and David Barker Maltby Award winner, 2011. Giselle is currently participating in North Sur, a photo exchange project for PANAMANIA, commissioned by the Arts and Culture Program of the TORONTO 2015 Pan Am and Parapan Am Games.


Youth working in Gallery 44 Darkroom, 2014


2015 Community Partners

“Nia’s partnership with Gallery 44 has a profound impact on young photographers”—Mark Campbell, executive director, Nia Centre for the Arts 
Gallery 44 works collaboratively with community groups serving youth to provide a program that can be customized to the needs of the participants. Qualified photographers with a personal connection to each community organization teach the hands-on photography workshops. 

Nia Centre for the Arts
Eva’s Phoenix
Toronto Council Fire Native Cultural Centre
PEACH
UrbanArts

With a long history of supporting education in the arts, Gallery 44 hosts an expanded public education program targeted at specific audiences within and beyond the arts community.

Gallery 44’s OUTREACH program embodies our commitment to engaging Toronto’s youth in the arts, by democratizing photography and supporting a new generation of image-makers and visual thinkers. We hope you will join us, and reach out for OUTREACH!


Our needs and how you can help

In order to offer 40 workshops, we need to raise $5,000 for materials. Material fees are $125-$150 per workshop which covers the costs of photographic paper, film, processing, chemistry, snacks and transit tokens. We actively fundraise and receive support from foundations and corporations in order to cover other costs of the program, including instructor fees, facilities and classroom space rentals.

Individual contributions are essential to this program – Help us reach our goal by contributing to Reach out for OUTREACH!

You can offer your support at any level. At various levels, we are offering added perks of artwork, or a special dinner for you and 5 friends.

Any amount – Our gratitude + a social media shout out!


$75 or more – One of four limited edition digital prints, selected from the OUTREACH exhibition

$250 or more – All four limited edition digital prints, selected from the OUTREACH exhibition (Retail value $200, charitable tax receipt issued for $50)

$500 or more – A unique archival silver gelatin print, printed by an artist in our darkroom, framed and ready for your home gallery (Retail value $400, charitable tax receipt issued for $100)

$1500 or more – 
The first donor to support at this level will receive a private dinner for 6 at Food Dude’s Commissary Kitchen (24 Carlaw Ave, Toronto, ON) in the Private Tasting Room (Retail value $1200, charitable tax receipt issued for $300)

Any other donors to support at this level will become an ARCHIVAL 44 FRIEND of Gallery 44. This entitles them to a private photography workshop lead by a professional artist, and other benefits outlined on our website.


Please note: we will issue charitable tax receipts upon request for any donation above $100, minus the retail value of your selected perk.

Our Charitable Registration #119247310RR0001


Potential Challenges

If we don’t reach our funding goal, the program will have to be scaled back, with a smaller number of participants and fewer workshops. So please give generously, share generously, and help increase access to the arts!

Remember, Indiegogo charges a 5% higher fee if we don't reach our funding goal -- so please help us reach our goal! 

Photo by Rodrigo Castro, OUTREACH participant 2015

“Former participants have moved on to do great things in our communities. From organizing youth photography workshops at SEYA (South Etobicoke Youth Assembly) and the Access Alliance Multicultural Health & Community Services, organizing and participating in independent exhibitions, to attending post-secondary programs in various areas such as graphic design and epidemiology, the youth become socially engaged and active members of the cultural community.”—soJin Chun, G44 Head of Education & Outreach

Toronto Star coverage of Outreach participant Leilah Dhore's photography practice (Nov. 14, 2014)


Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to contribute? There are plenty of ways to help.

  • Share this campaign! This helps us reach a wider audience and spread the word about this vital program:
    Share link:  igg.me/at/reachout2015
    Facebook event: http://bit.ly/reachoutFB
  • Change your profile picture on social media and include the hashtag #reachoutG44
  • Attend the OUTREACH exhibition July 17 - August 1, 2015 (Reception July 17, 6 - 8 PM) and show the participants your support! Held at Gallery 44 Centre for Contemporary Photography, Suite 120, 401 Richmond St W, Toronto, ON


Image credit for main image: Setti Kidane from Nia Centre for the Arts

story:
Our Story

My name is Dino Mangano, and I am a high school teacher, as well as a freelance photographer  One of my passions, in addition to photography, is wine, specifically Michigan wine.  Most of America knows about the West Coast wineries, but very few know about the amazing wines made here on the "North Coast".  My dream is to create a Michigan Wineries Photo Book that is as vibrant, unique, and appealing as the wineries and vineyards it will contain.

 

The Impact

Not only will this book be a wonderful collectors item, but it will help to open the eyes of American wine lovers to the special wines created here in Michigan, a State that is in dire need of positive economic growth.  We have award winning wines that rival those in more well known regions, and some incredibly beautiful landscape to grow them on.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This plan will not be overly expensive, but fundraising is still necessary.  I will need to take a 3-4 day photo excursion to the Leelaneau and Old Mission Peninsulas, during August or September (when grapes are their fullest).  I'll need funding to cover basic trip costs (lodging, food, gas, etc).  Once done, I'll need funds for editing, printing and publishing.  My goal is to do all this for $1000.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word!  This project can help not only a blossoming photographer, but also lend a helping hand to a wonderful area of a wonderful State.

Not only will this book be a wonderful collectors item, but it will help to open the eyes of American wine lovers to the special wines created here in Michigan, a State that is in dire need of positive economic growth.  We have award winning wines that rival those in more well known regions, and some incredibly beautiful landscape to grow them on.
 


What We Need & What You Get
This plan will not be overly expensive, but fundraising is still necessary.  I will need to take a 3-4 day photo excursion to the Leelaneau and Old Mission Peninsulas, during August or September (when grapes are their fullest).  I'll need funding to cover basic trip costs (lodging, food, gas, etc).  Once done, I'll need funds for editing, printing and publishing.  My goal is to do all this for $1000.
 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Please spread the word!  This project can help not only a blossoming photographer, but also lend a helping hand to a wonderful area of a wonderful State.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Neil and I currently reside in Arizona.  Since 1996 I was in Law Enforcement. In 2008 I was forced out of career due to pain in my upper back and neck.  The doctors couldn't diagnose the problem for three years, but they finally found out what was causing so much pain.  Late last year I was required to have surgery on my neck, fusing the C4-C6 vertebrae, thus ending any chance of returning to Law Enforcement.  Now, I'm forced to start all over at the age of 42.  This is the toughest thing I've ever had to do, however, I have decided that since I must make a new start in life, I am going to do something I love to do, which is photography.  Now, here's the problem I face.

Three years of doctor's visits, ending in a surgical procedure has drained my pension and my savings. Like millions of people out there, I struggle with making ends meet.  My wife is on Disability and it is the only income we have.  Unfortunately, it barely covers our costs of living.  We have had to sell of many of our possessions, to include our vehicles, just to maintain a roof over our heads. But, God has blessed me with a talent that can help me and my family stay above the proverbial water line. 

The biggest issue I'm facing at the moment is the fact that no one wants to take me seriously enough to give me a paying job.  The reason for that isn't the quality of my work, but the equipment that I have.  You see, I'm currently using a Nikon Coolpix L120.  Great camera, in fact, everything posted in the Gallery section was taken with it.  But, if you ask any photographer out there, today, they'll tell you that to get a serious job, you need serious equipment.  If you look like an amateur, you'll be treated like one.

Now, I have two choices. Either I dwell on what was lost, or put my heart and soul into another dream I've had since I was young. You guessed it, I'm going to put everything I have into my passion for photography. Speaking of passion, I can think of nothing more symbolically passionate than a Sunset. Not just any Sunset, though, I'm talking about the kind of Sunsets you can only find in the Deserts and Mountains of Arizona. Not to mention the Grand Canyon. How often can you say that you've seen the Sun set over one of the 7 Great Wonders of the World? I want to bring this kind of passion to you via my photography. Unfortunately, there's something lost in it that can only be captured with a DSLR. And this is where you come in.

If you look off the right of your screen, you'll see some perks for donating. These perks might seem trivial, afterall, who am I to send out autographed photos, right? I"m the guy thats going to make a big splash in the world of Photography and when I do, these early prints that I'm offering here will only go up in value. Now, if you can't afford to donate cash, there's another option. If you have used equipment you would like to donate you can contact me at neilorrphotography@gmail.com and I will give you a shipping address.  Every little bit helps.  Thank you and God Bless.

 

All donors  of $10.00 or more will recieve a signed 8x10 photo of their choice from my website http://neilorrphoto.tumblr.com/

The remaining money will be used to distribute the rewards and pay for the funding.

The Impact

This equipment will have an impact on the quality of my work and the ability for me to support my wife and myself.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help.  The following equipment donations would also be of help, as well:

  • Lighting
  • Back Drops
  • Bag
  • Lens

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
I'm homeless photographer. I lost my apartment in early September. I was evicted. I now live a few days in flats of different friends, I do not know how long it will be possible. Most of my belongings are in warehouse bailiff. I photograph a borrowed cameras and my canon S40. I use the Internet in cafes, libraries and at friends. I want to recover my belongings from the bailiff, move them to the my warehouse, rent an apartment. I collect money for a new start in life - the purchase of photographic equipment and computer, rent a flat, urgent current needs .
I live in Poland.
Jacek Lidwin

My belongings in warehouse bailiff:


My former bed in the colleague's flat, I do not live there anymore


My temporary ex neighbor:

story:
We are a group of 14 seventh and eighth graders from a Montessori Middle School. Through hard work and dedication, we are fundraising money by selling handmade products. For one week, we design sculptures out of recycled bike parts and take photographs, letting our creativity flow while stimulating our evolving minds. The photographs taken are turned into a variety of things, such as coasters, mouse-pads, notebooks, calendars, and cards, while the sculptures are sold to raise money in the hope of future chances to engage in immersive learning outside of school.

   The money raised is used to give us opportunities to go on field trips and provide us with extracurricular educational experiences.  One of the most prominent weeks we focus on in the Middle School is Drama Week. During Drama Week we develop our skills in the performing arts by writing short stories and bringing them to life in plays. During Drama Week, students focus on building their self-confidence and working with each other.  

   There are other purposes for our fundraising, too.  Near the end of the year, we go to a three-day sleep-away camp; the University of Arizona’s Sky School on Mt. Lemmon. There, our work is mostly centered around astronomy.  We also research other fields of science as well, like geology, ecology, and engineering. 

   We make our metal art by going to a bike shop that recycles old bike parts and turns them into artistic pieces. Our group designed multiple metal pieces of artwork that were later welded by a professional welder, including a coffee table, candleholders, a jellyfish, and flowers. To create our unique photographs, we walked around the University of Arizona campus taking high-quality pictures of our urban and desert setting. We hope that you enjoy the work we have spent this week doing and will help us reach our goal of 2,000 dollars. Thank you! 

Continue to scroll down to see the different types of candle holders you are able to purchase, as well as the pictures we took. You are also able to choose which picture you want for some of the items by commenting the number of the picture you would like for the item.

story:
THE CAMPAIGN IS OVER NOW
THANK YOU FOR SUPPORTING AND SHARING IT.
EVEN THOUGH WE DID NOT REACH THE GOAL, THE BOOK WILL BE PRINTED AND EVERYONE WILL GET WHAT HE PAID FOR

If you wanna buy the book now, you can buy it here.

DEUTSCH  - - - - -  ITALIANO

The project:

"DOLOMITI, see them, love them" is a premium quality photo-book about the Dolomites. The book is the first part of the long-term project ''I love the Dolomites' to document the Dolomites in all their aspects.

The Dolomites

are widely regarded as being among the most attractive mountain landscapes in the world.
(UNESCO, STATEMENT OF OUTSTANDING UNIVERSAL VALUE, CRITERION VII:
to contain superlative natural phenomena or areas of exceptional natural beauty and aesthetic importance)


The book includes:  

  • 120 images (with GPS-coordinates of the peaks and the point of view)
  • 50 hand-drawn illustrations of the areas
  • My top-10 Vie Ferrate
  • Information about "Alte Vie delle Dolomiti"
  • information for summer and winter sports (vie ferrate, climbing, biking, skiing)
  • historical and geolocial facts
  • All the huts and tourist information offices including email, phone and website (+ GPS data)


Why I need your help:
I invested a lot of effort, time and money to take the pictures and collect all the material. At this point I need your help to cover the initial costs of the print process. The first production run to print a high quality book is costly.

The quality of the book:
The book will be a hard cover, landscape format (31,5cm x 24,5cm), high quality paper, printed by one of the best book printers in Italy. The pictures were taken with high-quality cameras with amazing details.You will enjoy this quality from the first moment you will hold the book in your hands. It's a photo-book for mountain-lovers, hikers, climbers, explorers and everybody interested in the unique beauty this mountains offer.

About me:

I am a photographer / designer living in the Dolomites. The last ten years I spent every free minute I had hiking and climbing up to special spots to take pictures, make timelapse movies and collect informations about the Dolomites, the so called pale mountains.

I collected a lot of material! Really a lot!
NOW it's time to share the beauty of the mountains I love with you.

My goal is to make a premium quality, 200 page hardcover book with all the relevant informations about the Dolomites. Along with the book there will be the website 'i Love the Dolomites' delivering additional informations like GPS coordinates where the pictures have been taken.

How can you get involved?

  • Buy the book
  • Spread the word of this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, your blog, website, ...

THANK YOU!!!

for supporting this campaign and for sharing it with your friends!


>>> DEUTSCHE PROJEKTBESCHREIBUNG

Das Projekt
"Dolomiti: see them, love them" ist der Versuch einen Bildband mittels Crowdfounding in Eigenregie zu veröffentlichen. Das Buch beinhaltet:

  • 150 Bilder
  • Illustrationen der Gipfel und Gebiete
  • Meine 10 Favoriten der Vie Ferrate
  • Informationen zu den 10 "Alte Vie delle Dolomiti"
  • Historische und Geologische Informationen
  • Die Hütten inklusive Telefonnummer, email und Website


Hinzu kommen die GPS-Daten bei den Aufnahmen, sowohl jene der fotografierten Gipfel als auch des Aufnahmenstandpunktes. Dies dürfte für allem für Fotografen und aufmerksame Wanderer sehr interessant sein.


>>> DESCRIZIONE ITALIANA

Il progetto
"Dolomiti: see them, love them" è un volume illustrato sulle Dolomiti. Il libro contiene:

  • 150 immagini
  • illustrazioni delle aree e vette
  • Le mie 10 Vie Ferrate preferite
  • Informazioni sulle 10 "Alte vie delle Dolomiti"
  • Informazioni geologiche e storiche
  • I rifugi (telefono, mail e sito web)

Inoltre il libro contiene i dati GPS delle vette fotografate con i dati del punto da dove la foto è stata fatta. Dati interessanti per fotografi e chi ha gli occhi ben aperti per gustarsi in pieno le Dolomiti.

story:
The stretch goal of 1400€. If we get there, I can finally buy an all black hussar jacket and make a portrait with it! And I could also continue the making of blog until the hussar jacket picture has been made.


The Hunters

Hi! My name is Juha Arvid Helminen, I'm a photographer from Finland and I wish to make a new art work dealing with the subject of hunting endangered species and the destruction of biodiversity. The idea is to share the project from making of the work to the exhibition with you in a private blog.

The image will end up on a GALLERY WALL IN IRELAND for my solo exhibition this summer! And everyone who buys a postcard or more, will get their name on a thank you list for sponsors in the gallery, if they so choose.
I will also make a thank you video from the gallery opening and post it in the private blog. Naturally I hope to see as many of you in the opening event, 16th* of June 2016 in Gallery X! 

You can find more about my art work in these features: Hi-Fructos and Georgie Magazine. 

*The opening day may change.

About the New Work

I have started to shift slowly towards other art projects but the Hunter image would be a great addition to The Invisible Empire series. I want to also share the making of process with you and offer the possibility to buy an affordable art print.

I don't have problems with hunting for food. But I do have a problem with trophy hunting when an animal is killed merely for its antlers or the head and the rest of the carcass goes to waste. Also killing endangered species is a huge problem. I want this image to reflect these aspects.

In general, mystery intrigues me – that not every character's motive is explained, leaving questions unanswered. Questions on top of questions describes my work well. This new artwork would be dedicated to those, who helped to me make this project come true.


Reference Material and Concept Drawings

Above are some reference images and below concept drawings of the images and the outfits. I will also make portraits for the triptych. There would be about four new pictures in all.

The idea is to have four male and one female characters. Stylish wool tunicks and some accessories. The outfits and guns would have a look from the 1800-1900.


The Invisible Empire 

Here are some samples of my art work. All the new work would be made in the same black on black style. The main image of The Hunters would be a group photo in the same style as the Cabinet but with four to five characters.

The Cabinet

The Imperial Uhlans

In the Name of Tradition

Queen of the Invisible Empire                          Black Wedding


What Do You Get?

The Postcard

The thank you postcard in standard size will be hand written by me and sent as soon as the art work and printing is done. I will select the best image of the new set to make this card.

The Prints

To keep the shipping cost low, all the prints are sold unframed. They come in a thick shipping tube, numbered and signed. These c-prints (a real photo print) last for a long, long time – just don't put them to direct sunlight or expose to UV light. You can select the print from one of the upcoming group photos. I have sold photo prints to all over the world so you are in good hands.

All prints have extra white borders around the image like in this example of Black Wedding.


The Private Blog!

This one will be cool! I will share the progress of the whole project in a private blog: photos, texts and videos. It's a step by step insight about how I make the artwork.
As you can see below, a lot is needed to make this kind of photos. In the blog I will share some of my outfit and prop collection with you in photos and videos.
I will continue this private blog at least to the opening of the Dublin exhibition so I can share the whole process of making an exhibition happen.


The Scarp Books!

I will only make three of the scrap books and they all will be unique: hand written in white ink to black pages. The books will have small photos of my work and making of pictures, reference material and other clippings related to my art work and this project. About 30 pages in all.


The Posters

A2 sized posters of either Black Wedding (see photo below) or the upcoming The Hunters. The text layout style for the new poster will be the same but the poster might be a horizontal one. I will select the best image for the poster when the images are made. The new poster will be printed in a glossy paper. The posters come in a standard shipping tube which is inside a cardboard triangle.


Custom poster!

This is a custom made A2 size Epson print out poster. Just info me what image from the older The Invisible Empire photos you wish to have! The layout is the same as with Black Wedding poster. 


Where Does the Money Go to?

To make this project happen, these are the things I need: 

 - A prop shotgun, a rifle or a musket (I can't use a real gun) 

 - New accessories 

 - Studio time 

 - Money to travel to DUBLIN, IRELAND!

 - Printing the postcards and the poster

 - Making the art prints 

+ other expenses. Also I need to pay for Indiegogo's and Paypal's charges, as well as taxes.


Risks & Challenges

The project is well planned and budgeted but since it's an art project, it will grow during the process. So, the final work won't be exactly like the drafts but even better! I've heard that some postcards have gone missing in post in similar projects, but I believe everyone will eventually get theirs. The art prints, posters and scrap book will have a tracking number. 
And please remember that the possible customs and tax fees in your country are yours to pay. All the perks include VATax already. For postcards, posters and the scrap books the VAT is 24%, for fine art prints 10%.


Have No Funds For This But Want To Help?

Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.

Use the Indiegogo share tools on your social media. 

Thank you so much!

Best,

Juha Arvid Helminen

Ps: I really hope we can make this happen!

My Dear Brothers

The idea is to have four male and one female characters. Stylish wool tunicks and some accessories. The outfits and guns would have a look from the 1800-1900.






The Invisible Empire 
Here are some samples of my art work. All the new work would be made in the same black on black style. The main image of The Hunters would be a group photo in the same style as the Cabinet but with four to five characters.

The Cabinet

The Imperial Uhlans

In the Name of Tradition


Queen of the Invisible Empire                          Black Wedding

What Do You Get?

The Postcard
The thank you postcard in standard size will be hand written by me and sent as soon as the art work and printing is done. I will select the best image of the new set to make this card.
The Prints
To keep the shipping cost low, all the prints are sold unframed. They come in a thick shipping tube, numbered and signed. These c-prints (a real photo print) last for a long, long time – just don't put them to direct sunlight or expose to UV light.

You can select the print from one of the upcoming group photos. I have sold photo prints to all over the world so you are in good hands.

All prints have extra white borders around the image like in this example of Black Wedding.

The Private Blog!
This one will be cool! I will share the progress of the whole project in a private blog: photos, texts and videos. It's a step by step insight about how I make the artwork.As you can see below, a lot is needed to make this kind of photos. In the blog I will share some of my outfit and prop collection with you in photos and videos.I will continue this private blog at least to the opening of the Dublin exhibition so I can share the whole process of making an exhibition happen.



The Scarp Books!
I will only make three of the scrap books and they all will be unique: hand written in white ink to black pages. The books will have small photos of my work and making of pictures, reference material and other clippings related to my art work and this project. About 30 pages in all.






The Posters
A2 sized posters of either Black Wedding (see photo below) or the upcoming The Hunters. The text layout style for the new poster will be the same but the poster might be a horizontal one. I will select the best image for the poster when the images are made. The new poster will be printed in a glossy paper. The posters come in a standard shipping tube which is inside a cardboard triangle.



Custom poster!
This is a custom made A2 size Epson print out poster. Just info me what image from the older The Invisible Empire photos you wish to have! The layout is the same as with Black Wedding poster. 




Where Does the Money Go to?

To make this project happen, these are the things I need: 

 - A prop shotgun, a rifle or a musket (I can't use a real gun) 
 - New accessories 
 - Studio time 
 - Money to travel to DUBLIN, IRELAND!
 - Printing the postcards and the poster
 - Making the art prints 
+ other expenses. Also I need to pay for Indiegogo's and Paypal's charges, as well as taxes.
Risks & Challenges The project is well planned and budgeted but since it's an art project, it will grow during the process. So, the final work won't be exactly like the drafts but even better!

I've heard that some postcards have gone missing in post in similar projects, but I believe everyone will eventually get theirs. The art prints, posters and scrap book will have a tracking number. And please remember that the possible customs and tax fees in your country are yours to pay. All the perks include VATax already. For postcards, posters and the scrap books the VAT is 24%, for fine art prints 10%.

    Have No Funds For This But Want To Help?
Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
Use the Indiegogo share tools on your social media. 
Thank you so much!  Best,Juha Arvid HelminenPs: I really hope we can make this happen!My Dear Brothers

story:
My name is Peter Gatt and I am the founder of the Photographic Museum of Ontario. The P.M.O. was founded in 2009 and is a non-profit organization with charity status.    

In Ontario, there isn’t a single museum that is dedicated to Photography and its’ related artifacts. There are many people who are passionate about photography and have their own collection. However, as these are private collections, the general public never has a chance to see them. This is why I started the Photographic Museum of Ontario.

In the 1995 Kodak Canada sold their 55-Acre property in Toronto as a means to downsize. Metrus Properties purchased that land in order to build mega box stores. The citizens of Weston (a small area in Toronto) protested this idea for many years. With continuing resistance from local residents, Metrus Properties sold the land to Metrolinx. Now the property is slated to become a subway hub and the last remaining building is designated to become offices.

We need to preserve our photographic history and particularly in the City where photography truly began in Canada. At this point in time, most levels of government are not interested in helping with the start up of the museum. The onus will be on the generosity of the public.

We are now in communication with Metrolinx to purchase or lease this historic property to preserve our history. The cost to purchase and renovate will run into the millions. Thus your generous donations will be essential to the success of our museum.

All donations to the Photographic Museum of Ontario will receive a Canadian tax receipt. Any amount is greatly appreciated. 

Thank you for you time and generosity. Please spread the word about our mission.

For updates on the museum, or to make a donation, please visit: www.photographicmuseumofontario.org

 

Thank you,

 

Peter Gatt
